Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Downloads for Latest Version of Package Incorrectly Shows as 0" (#8971) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

My team owns https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.WebJobs.Extensions.Sql/ and recently pushed a new version of this package to NuGet.org.

Since then, download numbers on NuGet have stayed at 0 on this latest version (0.1.207-preview), but we know that customers are using this, as we have signals from elsewhere (even including GitHub issues) that show folks are trying this out.

This makes it harder for us to assess usage for this package, and we like to report on package download numbers.

### Repro Steps

1. On https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Azure.WebJobs.Extensions.Sql/
2. Downloads show as 0 for 0.1.207-preview

### Expected Behavior

Downloads do not show as 0.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40371649/151888859-c8fa89df-33a2-47e9-9b1f-3a937b1d7cad.png)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Use table-responsive for sample glob descriptions." (#8974) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8919
This was being caused by a table in the API keys page being wider than the page when zoomed in.
This behaviour could also be replicated by making the window very narrow.
Update this table to use BootStrap's table-responsive, which causes the table content to correctly collapse with page width.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Remove the original package details page" (#8977) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "[A11y]Update statistics chart to resize correctly." (#8972) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8920
Turns out this was actually caused by a bug where the data being sent in on resize was actually a null object, which broke the graph for the rest of the session.
This update passes in the object that is attached to the window on page load instead and should prevent the graph data being lost.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Update to latest SharpZipLib to resolve CG alert" (#8976) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Verified locally. SharpZipLib is a dependency of the local, Lucene-based search indexing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove original package details page" (#8975) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Currently Gallery has two versions of the package details page due to a recent redesign. We maintain both versions currently.

### The Elevator Pitch

 Now that we've shipped the redesign, we should drop the previous version.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Resolve Dependabot warnings about Bootstrap dependencies" (#8973) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This resolves the pending Dependabot alerts shown on GitHub.

I made this against `main` so we can see the fix immediately. No runtime change verified by running `grunt`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet list package outdated doesn't suggest stable version" (#11439) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Create simple console app then add Serilog  2.10.0-dev-01245.
When you do `dotnet list package outdated`, it should suggest "2.10" stable according to VS.

```
   [netcoreapp3.1]:
   Top-level Package         Requested             Resolved              Latest
   > Serilog                 2.10.0-dev-01245      2.10.0-dev-01245      2.11.0-dev-01377
```
![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5eb1d84a3cd56675c3efe510/f683c112-174e-4c65-b7ad-3e11d344a561)

Output for `dotnet list package outdated --include-prerelease` is fine.

```
   [netcoreapp3.1]:
   Top-level Package         Requested             Resolved              Latest
   > Serilog                 2.10.0-dev-01245      2.10.0-dev-01245      2.11.0-dev-01377
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Versions dropdown default selection should be LatestStable on Updates tab in PM UI" (#11537) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Dev\6.2.0.29

### Worked before?

Dev\6.2.0.28

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a C# Console App (.NET Core) project.
2. Open PM UI of the project by right-clicking the project->Manage NuGet Packages‚Ä¶ in Solution Explorer.
3. Install a package (e.g. ‚ÄúNewtonsoft.Json‚Äù), not the latest one (e.g. ‚Äú11.0.1‚Äù).
4. Click the ‚ÄúUpdates‚Äù Tab.

## Expected:
The Latest Stable version should show in the "Version" dropdown box as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/151691090-06362ca4-a956-468d-849c-56fecea85188.png)

## Actual:
The version shows in the "Version" dropdown box as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/151691096-d816ab5f-d075-4a9b-8972-aa7daf820e30.png)

## Notes:
1. The issue also reproes on C# Console App (.NET Framework) project with the Packages.Config format.
2. The issue starts to repro from NuGet Client Dev\6.2.0.29, it doesn't repro on NuGet Client Dev\6.2.0.28.
3. The issue still repro after pressing the "Refresh" button.


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: The ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button is still clickable after typing an invalid version of the package " (#11424) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.1.066

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a new Console App (.Net Core) project.
2. Right-click the project and open Manage NuGet Packages in Solution Explorer.
3. Search a package (Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk) in PM UI.
4. Type an invalid version of the package in the right panel.

## Expected
The ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button is non-clickable.

## Actual
The ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button is still clickable after typing an invalid version of the package as below screenshot.
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/144211986-d87b70ac-b587-4c52-9a31-0cd51c9d3b1b.png)

## Note
The issue doesn't repro on Dev\6.1.0.64.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: The ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù button is still clickable after installing a package with latest version in PM UI" (#11423) at NuGet/Home

2. The issue doesn't  repro on  switching from "Installed" tab to "Browse" tab.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Package unusable after pack" (#11536) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

6.0.100

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

I'm in the process of configuring builds for an open source project which can be found here: https://github.com/atrauzzi/protoculture-dotnet-postgres

Part of how this project works is that it **embeds** various versions of postgres as static dependencies.  Those dependencies are to be included in the package and copied to the build output folder of any consuming projects.

If you look at [my `.csproj` file](https://github.com/atrauzzi/protoculture-dotnet-postgres/blob/main/Protoculture.Postgres.Embedded/Protoculture.Postgres.Embedded.csproj#L27-L34), you can see that I'm telling it to recursively grab a directory and eventually include it in the nuget package.

You can see in [the build](https://github.com/atrauzzi/protoculture-dotnet-postgres/runs/4994959039), packaging seems to succeed, but when I go to upload to the GitHub package repository as a test, I get the error:

```
warn : nupkg malformed - failed to extract metadata from upload. Are you sure this is a nupkg file?
```

Not helpful, but I tried out some nupkg validators and I end up getting the following:

```
Could not load file or assembly '/tmp/Protoculture.Postgres.Embedded.0.1.1-pre/contentFiles/postgres/windows/x86_64/lib/_int.dll'. The module was expected to contain an assembly manifest.
```

I definitely am copying `dll` files to that path in the package, but they are dependencies of the applications I'm embedding.  They do not in any way participate directly with my own application code.

As best as I can tell -- and the documentation for this kind of stuff is really spotty -- I can't seem to find a way to tell nuget/nupkg to not try to do anything with those files.  Thus it's preventing the package from working anywhere.

### Verbose Logs

You can see all configuration and attempted builds over at the project.

---

Feel free to also check out [my twitter thread](https://twitter.com/alextrauzzi/status/1487828270779224064) as I start asking around about this issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: [Bug Bash] The ‚ÄúPackageReference‚Äù package icon colors in Solution Explorer window are inconsistent between .NET SDK based project and .NET Framework project" (#11531) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.2.0.26

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

### Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\6.2.0.26
VS Version: Main\32127.271
OS: Windows-11-Enterprise-21H2
### Detailed repro steps
1. Launch VS and click ‚ÄúCreate a new project‚Äù button in the G2C dialog.
2. Create a C# ASP.NET Core Web App (.NET Core 6.0) project and a C# Console Application (.NET Framework 4.8) project separately in two VS instances.
3. Open the PM UI of every project and go to ‚ÄúBrowse‚Äù tab.
4. Select a package and install it into each project with ‚ÄúPackageReference‚Äù format.
5. Go to the Solution Explorer window and observe the installed package icon.
### Expected
The ‚ÄúPackageReference‚Äù package icon color in Solution Explorer window should be consistent.
### Actual
The ‚ÄúPackageReference‚Äù package icon colors in Solution Explorer window are inconsistent as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/151561512-7d1b9d35-69aa-45ee-be44-12cdb3997402.png)
### Notes
It‚Äôs not a regression.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Toolbox Item Population problem from Referenced NuGet package (WPF, .NET, VS Professional 2017 Version 15.6.6)" (#11515) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Package Manager 4.6.0, .NET Framework 4.6.1, Visual Studio Professional 2017 Version 15.6.6

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Toolbox Item Population problem from Referenced NuGet package (WPF, .NET, VS Professional 2017 Version 15.6.6)

Links used/information read in order to try and solve the issue:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/guides/create-ui-controls
https://github.com/microsoft/xaml-designer-extensibility/blob/main/documents/toolbox-population.md

Versions:
NuGet Package Manager 4.6.0
.NET Framework 4.6.1
Visual Studio Professional 2017 Version 15.6.6

Problem:
After adding a VisualStudioToolsManifest.xml file to our NuGet package (containing a .dll with WPF User Controls) in the hopes of automatically upon installation of NuGet package populate the ‚ÄúXAML Designer/WPF‚Äù Toolbox with the items specified in the manifest-file ‚Äì it does not. The Group/Tab is created upon installation of NuGet package, but it is empty (no items).

If we, instead of installing the NuGet package, copy the project containing the WPF User Controls into the solution and add a reference to it (Project -> Add -> Reference‚Ä¶ -> Projects -> Check the checkbox for the project containing the WPF User Controls). The group AND the items appear. However, this functionality is exactly what we want when installing the NuGet package, and what we believed the VisualStudioToolsManifest.xml would help us with.

Also, if we go to the Toolbox, right click -> Choose Items -> Browse -> Navigate to the .dll that is installed with the NuGet package -> OK, the items are added to the Toolbox. Which should mean that there is nothing wrong with the .dll itself.

The NuGet package works in all other senses when installing (the custom controllers are shown in the XAML Designer view and the app compiles/runs with the custom controllers as expected).

The VisualStudioToolsManifest.xml looks like:
```
<FileList>
  <File Reference = "NameOfDLLFile.dll">
    <ContainsControls>True</ContainsControls>
    <ToolboxItems UIFramework="WPF" VSCategory="GenericGroup" BlendCategory="GenericGroup">
      <Item Type="Namespace.Namespace.NameOfControl" />
      <!‚ÄîMore Items-->
    </ToolboxItems>
  </File>
</FileList>
```

**To summarize:** The ‚ÄúGenericGroup‚Äù is created as a group/tab in the Toolbox, but it is empty.


### Verbose Logs

```shell
Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2017 
Version 15.6.6
VisualStudio.15.Release/15.6.6+27428.2037
Microsoft .NET Framework
Version 4.8.03752
Installed Version: Professional

Visual C++ 2017   00370-10003-57093-AA542
Application Insights Tools for Visual Studio Package   8.11.10402.2
C# Tools   2.7.0-beta3-62715-05. Commit Hash: db02128e6e3c4bdfc93e6ec425ac9162b4d4fe80
Command1 Extension   1.0
Common Azure Tools   1.10
Dotfuscator Community Edition   5.32.1.6167-6ce295ebd
IncrediBuild Build Acceleration   1.5.0.2
JavaScript Language Service   2.0
Microsoft JVM Debugger   1.0
Microsoft MI-Based Debugger   1.0
Microsoft Visual C++ Wizards   1.0
Microsoft Visual Studio VC Package   1.0

NuGet Package Manager   4.6.0

ProjectServicesPackage Extension   1.0
Syntax Visualizer   1.0
Visual Basic Tools   2.7.0-beta3-62715-05. Commit Hash: db02128e6e3c4bdfc93e6ec425ac9162b4d4fe80
WiX Toolset Visual Studio Extension   1.0.0.4
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: nuget packages don't download from .targets files when RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation is enabled " (#11294) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

dotnet --info (Version:   5.0.401)

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Create a targetfilename.targets file:
\<Project>
  \<ItemGroup>
    \<PackageReference Include="any package here" Version="add version here" >
      \<PrivateAssets>all\</PrivateAssets>
    \</PackageReference>
  \</ItemGroup>
\</Project>

In Directory.Build.props, add:
  \<Import Project="\<path>/targetfilename.targets" />

  \<PropertyGroup>
    \<RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation Condition=" '$(RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation)' == '' ">true </RestoreUseStaticGraphEvaluation>
  \</PropertyGroup>

Run "dotnet restore" and the package will not download. Works with msbuild /restore.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: LocalV3FindPackageByIdResource.GetAllVersionsAsync does not return any versions when local feed contains the package." (#11303) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet API nuget packages

### Product Version

I use the latest nuget v3 api packages in my own program (referenced to version `*-*`)

### Worked before?

I know what it worked on Windows with Nuget.Client, but since I need it to work xplat it will not work with the v3 apis.

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

I would take a look at the code file in action that I encounter the issue at. That is the only file that uses types from the nuget api packages. https://github.com/Elskom/installer/blob/main/src/NuGetHelper.cs

This should hopefully allow to help reproduce this. Basically I want that same code to be anle to process all sources even local ones that they added using `dotnet nuget add source`.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
I am not sure logs are possible in this case, perhaps this is an api bug.
```
